subject: Art
title: Layering & Glazing with Acrylics
description: Building up transparent and opaque layers for rich, complex surfaces.

hook.text: Acrylic's superpower: once dry, it's waterproof. This means you can paint transparent glazes over opaque layers without disturbing the paint beneath. Layer after layer, building richness like geological strata.

buildup.text: Layering strategy: 1) Opaque underpainting (block in values and colors). 2) Transparent glazes (build color richness). 3) Opaque highlights (pop the brightest areas). This opaque-transparent-opaque sandwich creates depth.

discovery.text: Glazing with acrylics: mix paint with glazing medium (keeps transparency without dilution). A blue glaze over a yellow base creates a luminous green that's richer than a mixed green because light bounces through separate color layers.

twist.text: Unlike oil, acrylic glazes dry in minutes, so you can apply dozens of glazes in a single session. Oil painters wait DAYS between glazes. This speed lets acrylic painters build complex layered effects that would take oil painters weeks.

climax.text: Paint a simple still life with an opaque underpainting. Once dry, apply 3-5 thin transparent glazes of different colors over different areas. The final painting will have a depth and luminosity that a single-layer painting can't match.

punchline.text: Acrylic layers are archaeological: each one adds history and depth. The painting becomes richer with every pass.

quiz.question: What is the advantage of acrylic glazing compared to oil glazing?
options: Acrylic dries in minutes, allowing dozens of glazes in one session vs days between oil glazes
